greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Square array read by descending antidiagonals: A(1,k) = A188163(k), and for n > 1, A(n,k) = A087686(1+A(n-1,k)).
comment: Square array A(n,k) [where n is row and k is column] is read by descending antidiagonals: A(1,1), A(1,2), A(2,1), A(1,3), A(2,2), A(3,1), etc.
For n >= 3, each row n lists the numbers that appear n times in A004001. See also A051135.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..210; the first 20 antidiagonals of array
Index entries for sequences that are permutations of the natural numbers
formula: For the first row n=1, A(1,k) = A188163(k), for rows n > 1, A(n,k) = A087686(1+A(n-1,k)).
example: The top left corner of the array:
program: (define (A265903bi row col) (if (= 1 row) (A188163 col) (A087686 (+ 1 (A265903bi (- row 1) col)))))
xref: For the known and suspected columns, see the rows listed for transposed array A265901.
Cf. A162598 (column index of n in array), A265332 (row index of n in array).
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Dec 18 2015
